clusters.title: Trump, Netanyahu discuss Gaza in phone call
clusters.neutral_headline: Netanyahu Seeks Pardon Amid Corruption Trial

items.title: Trump, Netanyahu discuss Gaza in phone call
items.standfirst: United States President Donald Trump spoke with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on the phone on Monday to discuss the situation in Gaza, the prime minister's office announced.The two leaders...
items.content: United States President Donald Trump spoke with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on the phone on Monday to discuss the situation in Gaza, the prime minister's office announced.The two leaders...

items.title: Mekelberg: Netanyahu's pardon request threatens judicial independence & Israel as liberal democracy
items.standfirst: "A very unusual request": Israeli President Isaac Herzog said he would focus only on Israel's "best interests" when he weighs Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's request for a pardon on corruption charges. Senior Consulting Fellow at Chatham House, Yossi Mekelberg argues, this is as much about the integrity of the judiciary, the separation of powers, and a deeply scarred nation, as it is about the soul of Israel’s democracy. “The idea that Netanyahu can actually continue to be prime minister while just stopping a corruption case is completely unacceptable,” asserts Mr. Mekelberg. If Herzog agrees to pardon, "he will probably compromise Israel’s liberal democracy and the independence of the judiciary.”
items.content: "A very unusual request": Israeli President Isaac Herzog said he would focus only on Israel's "best interests" when he weighs Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's request for a pardon on corruption charges. Senior Consulting Fellow at Chatham House, Yossi Mekelberg argues, this is as much about the integrity of the judiciary, the separation of powers, and a deeply scarred nation, as it is about the soul of Israel’s democracy. “The idea that Netanyahu can actually continue to be prime minister while just stopping a corruption case is completely unacceptable,” asserts Mr. Mekelberg. If Herzog agrees to pardon, "he will probably compromise Israel’s liberal democracy and the independence of the judiciary.”

items.title: Netanyahu seeking pardon from Israeli president for corruption trial
items.standfirst: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu submitted a request for a formal pardon from Israeli President Isaac Herzog for a yearslong corruption trial. NBC News' Hala Gorani reports on the stipulations of such a pardon and how that would impact Netanyahu politically.
items.content: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu submitted a request for a formal pardon from Israeli President Isaac Herzog for a yearslong corruption trial. NBC News' Hala Gorani reports on the stipulations of such a pardon and how that would impact Netanyahu politically.

items.title: What does Netanyahu want to be pardoned for and is it possible?
items.standfirst: The Israeli prime minister is facing corruption charges that could see him sentenced to up to 10 years in prison.
items.content: The Israeli prime minister is facing corruption charges that could see him sentenced to up to 10 years in prison.

items.title: Netanyahu seeks pardon on corruption charges after getting Trump's backing
items.standfirst: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has submitted a request for a formal pardon amid a yearslong corruption trial, just weeks after President Donald Trump said he should be pardoned.“Today, my lawyers submitted a request for clemency to the President of the State,” Netanyahu said in a video address posted on X Sunday.“The continuation of the trial is tearing us apart from within, provoking fierce divisions, intensifying divisions,” he said.
items.content: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has submitted a request for a formal pardon amid a yearslong corruption trial, just weeks after President Donald Trump said he should be pardoned.“Today, my lawyers submitted a request for clemency to the President of the State,” Netanyahu said in a video address posted on X Sunday.“The continuation of the trial is tearing us apart from within, provoking fierce divisions, intensifying divisions,” he said.

items.title: Benjamin Netanyahu asks Israel’s president for pardon in corruption case
items.standfirst: Request is submitted weeks after Donald Trump called on Isaac Herzog to pardon Israeli prime ministerBenjamin Netanyahu has asked Israel’s president for a pardon for bribery and fraud charges and an end to a five-year corruption trial, arguing that it would be in the “national interest”.Isaac Herzog’s office acknowledged receipt of the 111-page submission from the prime minister’s lawyer, and said it had been passed on to the pardons department in the ministry of justice. The president’s legal adviser would also formulate an opinion before Herzog made a decision, it added. Continue reading...
items.content: Request is submitted weeks after Donald Trump called on Isaac Herzog to pardon Israeli prime ministerBenjamin Netanyahu has asked Israel’s president for a pardon for bribery and fraud charges and an end to a five-year corruption trial, arguing that it would be in the “national interest”.Isaac Herzog’s office acknowledged receipt of the 111-page submission from the prime minister’s lawyer, and said it had been passed on to the pardons department in the ministry of justice. The president’s legal adviser would also formulate an opinion before Herzog made a decision, it added. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu requested a pardon from President Herzog for corruption charges.
Netanyahu faces corruption charges that could lead to a ten-year prison sentence.
President Trump previously stated Netanyahu should be pardoned for the charges.
The request comes weeks after Trump's statement of support for a pardon.
Some believe a pardon could compromise Israel's judicial independence.

items.title: Resident doctors in England to go on strike in run-up to Christmas
items.standfirst: Five days of strike action over jobs and pay to take place from 17 to 22 December Thousands of doctors in England are to go on strike again this month, in a dispute over pay and job security.The British Medical Association has announced that resident doctors – formerly known as junior doctors – will begin a five-day strike action that will run from 7am on 17 December until 7am on 22 December. The British Medical Association announced the strike action.

clusters.title: Latest on U.S. moves around Venezuela as Trump says he has confidence in Hegseth
clusters.neutral_headline: US Lawmakers Demand Answers Over Hegseth Venezuela Boat Strike Claims

items.title: Latest on U.S. moves around Venezuela as Trump says he has confidence in Hegseth
items.standfirst: CBS News' Charlie D'Agata and Olivia Rinaldi report on the Trump administration's latest actions around Venezuela amid a Washington Post report that Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth gave a verbal order to leave no survivors in the first U.S. strike on a suspected drug smuggling boat in the Caribbean.
items.content: CBS News' Charlie D'Agata and Olivia Rinaldi report on the Trump administration's latest actions around Venezuela amid a Washington Post report that Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth gave a verbal order to leave no survivors in the first U.S. strike on a suspected drug smuggling boat in the Caribbean.

items.title: Could Hegseth's apparent boat strikes orders rise to the level of a war crime?
items.standfirst: Democratic Sen. Tim Kaine told Nancy Cordes on "Face the Nation" that a report detailing apparent orders by Secretary of Defense Pete Hegseth on a Venezuelan boat strike "rises to the level of war crime if it's true." CBS News Pentagon reporter Eleanor Watson has more details.
items.content: Democratic Sen. Tim Kaine told Nancy Cordes on "Face the Nation" that a report detailing apparent orders by Secretary of Defense Pete Hegseth on a Venezuelan boat strike "rises to the level of war crime if it's true." CBS News Pentagon reporter Eleanor Watson has more details.

items.title: Republicans, Democrats call for reviews of U.S. strikes on alleged drug boats near Venezuela
items.standfirst: Republican and Democratic lawmakers are calling for congressional reviews of the deadly U.S. strikes against alleged drug boats in the Caribbean after Secretary of Defense Pete Hegseth denied a report regarding his orders on the matter. CBS News senior national security correspondent Charlie D'Agata has the latest.
items.content: Republican and Democratic lawmakers are calling for congressional reviews of the deadly U.S. strikes against alleged drug boats in the Caribbean after Secretary of Defense Pete Hegseth denied a report regarding his orders on the matter. CBS News senior national security correspondent Charlie D'Agata has the latest.

items.title: Venezuela: Hegseth allegedly ordered ‘kill everybody’ in second drug boat strike
items.standfirst: According to The Washington Post, US forces carried out a follow-up strike on a suspected Venezuelan drug boat in September after seeing two survivors of an initial strike clinging to the burning vessel. The report said US Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth had ordered troops to "kill everybody" on board the vessel – a claim Hegseth dismissed as "fake news".
items.content: According to The Washington Post, US forces carried out a follow-up strike on a suspected Venezuelan drug boat in September after seeing two survivors of an initial strike clinging to the burning vessel. The report said US Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth had ordered troops to "kill everybody" on board the vessel – a claim Hegseth dismissed as "fake news".

items.title: US lawmakers demand answers over Hegseth Venezuela boat strike claims
items.standfirst: Concern over media reports that the US military carried out a second strike killing survivors on a suspected drug boat prompts a bipartisan inquiry.
items.content: Concern over media reports that the US military carried out a second strike killing survivors on a suspected drug boat prompts a bipartisan inquiry.

ai_summary: Reports detail alleged orders by Secretary of Defense Hegseth on a Venezuelan boat strike.
The Washington Post reported Hegseth ordered troops to "kill everybody" on the vessel.
Hegseth denied the report, calling it "fake news".
Some lawmakers are calling for congressional reviews of the strikes.
Democratic Senator Kaine said the orders could be a war crime if true.

clusters.title: Supreme Court Questions $1 Billion Music Piracy Suit Against Cox

items.title: Supreme Court Questions $1 Billion Music Piracy Suit Against Cox
Supreme Court Questions $1 Billion Music Piracy Suit Against Cox
items.standfirst: The US Supreme Court weighed giving internet providers a stronger shield from legal liability when customers pirate copyrighted works, questioning a $1 billion music industry copyright lawsuit against Cox Communications Inc.
items.content: The US Supreme Court weighed giving internet providers a stronger shield from legal liability when customers pirate copyrighted works, questioning a $1 billion music industry copyright lawsuit against Cox Communications Inc.

items.title: Supreme Court weighs copyright fight between music industry and internet providers
items.standfirst: At issue is whether internet providers can be liable for their users' committing copyright violations using its services.
items.content: At issue is whether internet providers can be liable for their users' committing copyright violations using its services.(Image credit: Andrew Harnik)

ai_summary: The Supreme Court is weighing a copyright fight between the music industry and internet providers.
The case involves a $1 billion music industry copyright lawsuit against Cox Communications Inc.
The court is considering internet providers' liability for user copyright violations.
The court questioned giving internet providers a stronger shield from legal liability.
The case concerns whether internet providers can be held liable for copyright violations.

items.title: Sri Lanka and Indonesia deploy militaries as Asia floods death toll passes 1,100
items.standfirst: Millions of people affected by torrential rainfall in Sri Lanka and large parts of Indonesia’s Sumatra, southern Thailand and northern MalaysiaHow cyclones and monsoon rains combined to devastate parts of Asia – visual guideSri Lanka and Indonesia have deployed military personnel as they race to help victims of devastating flooding that has killed more than 1,100 people across four countries in Asia.Millions of people have been affected by a combination of tropical cyclones and heavy monsoon rains in Sri Lanka, parts of Indonesia’s Sumatra, Thailand and Malaysia in recent days. items.title: Sri Lanka braced for more damage after torrential rain kills hundreds across Asia
items.standfirst: Meanwhile, Iran grapples with one of worst droughts and temperatures fall 10C below normal in USMore heavy rainfall is expected in Sri Lanka in the coming days, likely resulting in further damage across the country. It comes after torrential rainfall in south-east Asia triggered catastrophic flash floods and landslides that have affected millions, killing more than 300 people in Indonesia and 160 in Thailand, with hundreds more still missing.Parts of North Sumatra, Indonesia, were hit with rainfall totals of 800mm over four days, with other areas also experiencing heavy rainfall. Continue reading...
items.content: Meanwhile, Iran grapples with one of worst droughts and temperatures fall 10C below normal in USMore heavy rainfall is expected in Sri Lanka in the coming days, likely resulting in further damage across the country. It comes after torrential rainfall in south-east Asia triggered catastrophic flash floods and landslides that have affected millions, killing more than 300 people in Indonesia and 160 in Thailand, with hundreds more still missing.Parts of North Sumatra, Indonesia, were hit with rainfall totals of 800mm over four days, with other areas also experiencing heavy rainfall. Continue reading...

items.title: Southeast Asia: At least 1,000 dead from flooding and landslides
items.standfirst: Sri Lanka and Indonesia deployed troops on Monday to assist survivors of severe flooding that has killed more than 1,000 people across four Asian countries.
items.content: Sri Lanka and Indonesia deployed troops on Monday to assist survivors of severe flooding that has killed more than 1,000 people across four Asian countries.

items.title: Death toll passes 900 in Indonesia, Thailand and Sri Lanka floods
items.standfirst: Officials in Indonesia say more than 442 people have died, while Sri Lanka suffers worst natural disaster since 2004 tsunami Authorities in Sri Lanka, Indonesia and Thailand are racing to clear debris and find hundreds of missing people after more than 900 died in devastating floods and landslides across the south of Asia.In the latest example of the impact of the climate crisis on storm patterns and extreme weather, heavy monsoon rains, exacerbated by a tropical storm, have overwhelmed parts of south-east Asia in recent days, leaving thousands of people stranded without shelter or critical supplies. Continue reading...
items.content: Officials in Indonesia say more than 442 people have died, while Sri Lanka suffers worst natural disaster since 2004 tsunami Authorities in Sri Lanka, Indonesia and Thailand are racing to clear debris and find hundreds of missing people after more than 900 died in devastating floods and landslides across the south of Asia.In the latest example of the impact of the climate crisis on storm patterns and extreme weather, heavy monsoon rains, exacerbated by a tropical storm, have overwhelmed parts of south-east Asia in recent days, leaving thousands of people stranded without shelter or critical supplies. Continue reading...

items.title: Sri Lanka’s capital hit by floods as cyclone death toll nears 200
items.standfirst: Hundreds of people still missing after heavy rain and mudslides in country’s deadliest natural disaster for yearsEntire areas of Sri Lanka’s capital are flooded after a powerful cyclone triggered heavy rains and mudslides across the island, with authorities reporting nearly 200 dead and dozens more missing.Officials said the extent of the damage in the country’s worst-affected central region was slowly becoming clear on Sunday as relief workers cleared roads blocked by fallen trees and mudslides. Continue reading...
items.content: Hundreds of people still missing after heavy rain and mudslides in country’s deadliest natural disaster for yearsEntire areas of Sri Lanka’s capital are flooded after a powerful cyclone triggered heavy rains and mudslides across the island, with authorities reporting nearly 200 dead and dozens more missing.Officials said the extent of the damage in the country’s worst-affected central region was slowly becoming clear on Sunday as relief workers cleared roads blocked by fallen trees and mudslides. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Floods and landslides have killed over 1,100 people across Asia.
Sri Lanka and Indonesia deployed military personnel to help victims.
Millions of people have been affected by the flooding.
Heavy rainfall is expected to continue in Sri Lanka.
The flooding was caused by a combination of cyclones and monsoon rains.
